docs.snippet: LEAD: The United States national soccer team, which struggled to score goals in qualifying for the 1990 World Cup finals this summer in Italy, struggled again tonight in its first game in more than two months.

Brady said today that a debt-reduction package that Mexico is about to sign with its commercial bankers would resolve that country's financial problems for the next three to four years, and predicted that similar agreements would soon be developed for the Philippines and Costa

headline.main: Brady Sees Plan Spreading To Other Developing Nations

docs.snippet: LEAD: Bob Gansler, the coach of the United States national soccer team, made it clear today that he was losing patience with players who have allowed peripheral issues, like contract disputes, to affect their preparation for the World Cup finals four...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Bob Gansler, the coach of the United States national soccer team, made it clear today that he was losing patience with players who have allowed peripheral issues, like contract disputes, to affect their preparation for the World Cup finals four months from now in Italy.

headline.main: Outside Distractions Affect U.S. Performance on Field And Leave Coach Angry

byline.original: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: LEAD: For William R. Rhodes of Citibank, yesterday was an end and a beginning. At the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, he joined officials from Mexico to sign an agreement to lower Mexico's $48.5 billion in debt with the more than 460 banks...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For William R. Rhodes of Citibank, yesterday was an end and a beginning. At the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, he joined officials from Mexico to sign an agreement to lower Mexico's $48.5 billion in debt with the more than 460 banks involved, winding up almost a year of tough negotiations that he led as co-chairman of the commerical bank advisory committee.

headline.main: For Citibank Official, An End and a Beginning

docs.snippet: LEAD: Six people were killed and at least 15 were injured when a bus carrying 35 passengers plunged off a bridge into a gully in northern Uruguay, the police said today. The accident happened about 330 miles northwest of Montevideo in a rainstorm...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Six people were killed and at least 15 were injured when a bus carrying 35 passengers plunged off a bridge into a gully in northern Uruguay, the police said today. The accident happened about 330 miles northwest of Montevideo in a rainstorm late Saturday, the police said.

docs.snippet: LEAD: World trade negotiators agreed today on a plan of action to liberalize trade in the $100 billion tropical products market, ending months of stalemate.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: World trade negotiators agreed today on a plan of action to liberalize trade in the $100 billion tropical products market, ending months of stalemate.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Back in 1977, when Miss Margarida, the redoubtable schoolteacher, first strode onto a New York stage, it did not take the audience long to figure out that they were in the hands of a rather unusual tyrant.

headline.main: Can a Dictator Tell Us Something About Ourselves?

byline.original: By ARIEL DORFMAN; Ariel Dorfman, a former Chilean exile, teaches literature at Duke University. His works include ''My House Is on Fire,'' a collection of stories published last month by Viking, and ''Widows,'' a play scheduled to open in May at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles

docs.snippet: LEAD:    TRACK AND FIELD       Elliott Sets 1,500-Meter Record    Peter Elliott of Britain set a world indoor record in the 1,500 meters of 3 minutes 34.21 seconds yesterday at the Placido Viagas Memorial meet yesterday in Seville, Spain. The...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD Elliott Sets 1,500-Meter Record Peter Elliott of Britain set a world indoor record in the 1,500 meters of 3 minutes 34.21 seconds yesterday at the Placido Viagas Memorial meet yesterday in Seville, Spain. The previous record of 3.35.6 was set by Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland on Feb.
